bibl.title: Letter from Harold C. Ernst to William H. Welch, October 30, 1908

div1.p: Ernst seeks advice on the status of the Carnegie Hero Fund application for Kissinger.

div1.head: Letter from Harold C. Ernst to William H. Welch, October 30, 1908
div1.opener:
Dr L
Harvard University Medical School
THE DEPARTMENT OF BACTERIOLOGY
240 LONGWOOD AVENUE,
BOSTON.
October 30, 1908.
My dear Doctor Welch:
div1.p:
I want to remind you of our conversation about John Kissinger, the yellow
fever patient, and to ask you what steps you would advise our taking. Can you
see Dr. Kelly in regard to it, and find out from him in what form the appeal
to the Carnegie Hero Fund was put, and see also whether there appears to be any
use in a concerted second attempt to secure recognition from that fund?

Miss Latimer, who wrote the letters that I showed you, was apparently Dr.
Kelly's secretary at the time he was getting ready the book “Walter Reed and
Yellow Fever,” writes to say that Kissinger has some spinal trouble, which has
disabled him so that he is unable to do anything further, and that his wife
also is breaking down. There appears to be a little money that will hold them
over the next two or three months, but nothing beyond that.

If you will give me your advice in the matter, I will undertake all cler-
ical details, because I think such a case should certainly be attended to.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, Harold C. Ernst. Dr. William H. Welch.
